dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, remember Bridgefy? That app that, like, gained a lot of attention during the Hong Kong protests back in 2019? It was supposed to be this, you know, mesh networking solution when the internet was cut.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, remember Bridgefy? That app that, like, gained a lot of attention during the Hong Kong protests back in twenty nineteen? It was supposed to be this, you know, mesh networking solution when the internet was cut.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As Forbes reported earlier this week, the app has seen download numbers spike due to the political crisis in the city... As with Firechat, Bridgefy uses a mesh network. That means smartphones use short-range Bluetooth connections to form their own network independent of the carrier cell masts and the internet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, I vaguely recall that. People were saying it was the new Firechat, a way to communicate off-grid, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, I vaguely recall that. People were saying it was the new Firechat, a way to communicate off-grid, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: it appears to have become the de facto offline messaging app replacing Firechat, which became popular during the 2014 pro-democracy protests. As with Firechat, Bridgefy uses a mesh network.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But, um, Forbes reported this week that its download numbers have totally tanked. Apparently, with, quote, "peace in the city," it's just become obsolete.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But, um, Forbes reported this week that its download numbers have totally tanked. Apparently, with, quote, peace in the city, it's just become obsolete.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As Forbes reported earlier this week, the app has seen download numbers spike due to the political crisis in the city...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Obsolete? That's, uh, that's kind of an ironic twist for an app meant for, like, *extreme* situations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Obsolete? That's, uh, that's kind of an ironic twist for an app meant for, like, extreme situations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it gets even more ironic, actually. The article says Bridgefy now, get this, employs a mesh network to ensure "absolute surveillance."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it gets even more ironic, actually. The article says Bridgefy now, get this, employs a mesh network to ensure absolute surveillance.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As with Firechat, Bridgefy uses a mesh network. That means smartphones use short-range Bluetooth connections to form their own network independent of the carrier cell masts and the internet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolute surveillance? Wait, so itâ€™s gone from a tool for protestors to... a tool *against* them?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolute surveillance? Wait, so it's gone from a tool for protestors to... a tool against them?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. It still uses short-range Bluetooth, but it's dependent on carrier cell masts and the internet. And authorities in Hong Kong and China? They've just easily shut it down.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. It still uses short-range Bluetooth, but it's dependent on carrier cell masts and the internet. And authorities in Hong Kong and China? They've just easily shut it down.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: smartphones use short-range Bluetooth connections to form their own network independent of the carrier cell masts and the internet. It should be difficult for authorities in Hong Kong, or China, to shut down the app.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So much for, like, being off-grid then. It sounds like it has a single point of failure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So much for, like, being off-grid then. It sounds like it has a single point of failure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There is no single point of failure that police could target to shut Bridgefy down.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, it does. Its central server. So, yeah, easily targeted. And here's the kicker: the riot cops, according to Forbes, "eagerly endorse Bridgefy."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, it does. Its central server. So, yeah, easily targeted. And here's the kicker: the riot cops, according to Forbes, eagerly endorse Bridgefy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There is no single point of failure that police could target to shut Bridgefy down.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles, disbelieving] Endorse it? Why would they... Oh, wait. I think I see where this is going.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Endorse it? Why would they... Oh, wait. I think I see where this is going.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yup. They actively encourage users to sign up! And then, uh, they use it to "coordinate operations." Like telling protestors to gather in locations *pre-approved by authorities*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yup. They actively encourage users to sign up! And then, uh, they use it to coordinate operations. Like telling protestors to gather in locations pre-approved by authorities.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Imagine a flurry of messages telling protestors to organize in a particular location, one where authorities are lying in wait.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So it's a trap. It's literally a honeypot for protestors. That's, that's messed up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's a trap. It's literally a honeypot for protestors. That's, that's messed up.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Or, you know, sharing messages about how officials are "peacefully managing the protests." Total propaganda.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or, you know, sharing messages about how officials are peacefully managing the protests. Total propaganda.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Or a message that caused panic by saying officials were violently shutting down protests in a certain location.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So what about the security side of things? Because if it's being used like this, there can't be much privacy, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So what about the security side of things? Because if it's being used like this, there can't be much privacy, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Matthew Green, a security expert from Johns Hopkins, he, um, he never even downloaded the app to review it. But he told Forbes there are "no security issues with Bridgefy."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Matthew Green, a security expert from Johns Hopkins, he, um, he never even downloaded the app to review it. But he told Forbes there are no security issues with Bridgefy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Matthew Green, associate professor at the Johns Hopkins Information Security Institute, downloaded the app to review its security and privacy. He told Forbes the main security issues with Bridgefy are the confidentiality and authenticity of any messages sent through untrusted third-party phones.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [skeptical] "No security issues"? That sounds like a red flag to me.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No security issues? That sounds like a red flag to me.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: He also said there's "no way to encrypt anything, and that's fine." Yeah, "fine" for a protest app.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He also said there's no way to encrypt anything, and that's fine. Yeah, fine for a protest app.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hypothetically these could be encrypted, but that requires key management. Im not sure how Bridgefy does this in a secure way when their servers are offline, added Green.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. And what did Bridgefy's spokesperson say about all this?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. And what did Bridgefy's spokesperson say about all this?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Their spokesperson claimed the app "does not use encryption," but then also said broadcast messages are "purposefully encrypted."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Their spokesperson claimed the app does not use encryption, but then also said broadcast messages are purposefully encrypted.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A Bridgefy spokesperson told Forbes the app does use encryption. We use end-to-end RSA encryption on private direct and mesh messaging... Broadcast messages are purposefully not encrypted, so everyone can read them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping, laughing softly] What?! So it doesn't, but it does? That's, uh, that's a level of contradiction I didn't expect.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: What?! So it doesn't, but it does? That's, uh, that's a level of contradiction I didn't expect.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And they guarantee it's "completely bulletproof," "100% reliable," no interception. "Privacy anxiety is not a thing."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they guarantee it's completely bulletproof, one hundred percent reliable, no interception. Privacy anxiety is not a thing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The spokesperson admitted, though, that no app can be bulletproof from snooping... Indeed, in the companys terms and conditions, Bridgefy notes: No security measure is 100% reliable and your content is subject to interception by third parties unaffiliated with Bridgefy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, boy. That just screams "don't trust us with your data."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, boy. That just screams don't trust us with your data.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Green actually praises Bridgefy's collection of metadata, *especially* if the police are running the app, because, you know, that metadata could never link back to you.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Green actually praises Bridgefy's collection of metadata, especially if the police are running the app, because, you know, that metadata could never link back to you.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Green also highlighted concerns about collection of metadata, especially if some people running the app are also police. That metadata could include a Bridgefy users mobile phone device identifier. That could then be used to determine the identity of the owner of the cellphone

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [sarcastically] Of course not. Governments would never ask carriers for user data.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Of course not. Governments would never ask carriers for user data.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And no threat of malware! So, uh, the conclusion?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And no threat of malware! So, uh, the conclusion?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Theres also the threat of a government spreading malware via the app with broadcasts pushing malicious links.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, this Bridgefy, it's just a completely useless tool for communicating in extreme situations?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, this Bridgefy, it's just a completely useless tool for communicating in extreme situations?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. Forbes sums it up: "Bridgefy is, without a doubt, a useless tool for communicating and organizing in extreme situations."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. Forbes sums it up: Bridgefy is, without a doubt, a useless tool for communicating and organizing in extreme situations.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But if they're willing to accept the risk, Bridgefy could remain a useful tool for communicating and organizing in extreme situations.
